'''Albert "Sunnyland Slim" Luandrew''' (September 5, 1906 – March 17, 1995)<ref name="aristocrat">{{cite web |url= http://myweb.clemson.edu/~campber/aristocrat.html|title= The Aristocrat Label|first= Robert L. |last= Campbell |coauthors= Robert Pruter, George R. White, Tom Kelly|date= July 31, 2009|work= |publisher= Red Saunders Research Foundation|accessdate=June 5, 2014}} "Blues pianist and singer Sunnyland Slim was born Albert Luandrew in Vance, Mississippi, September 5, 1906 (most sources say 1907, but the Social Security Death Index and 1920 census data give the date as 1906)." </ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[pianist]], who was born in the [[Mississippi Delta]], and later moved to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], to contribute to that city's post-[[World War II|war]] scene as a center for blues music.<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9112323/Sunnyland-Slim
|title=Sunnyland Slim - Britannica Online Encyclopedia
|publisher=www.britannica.com
|accessdate=2008-06-05}}</ref> Chicago's [[presenter|broadcaster]] and [[writer]], [[Studs Terkel]], said Sunnyland Slim was "a living piece of our [[folk music|folk]] history, gallantly and eloquently carrying on in the old tradition."<ref name="russell">{{cite book|first=Tony|last=Russell|year=1997|title=The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]]|edition=|publisher=Carlton Books Limited|location=Dubai|page=171
|isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref>

==Biography==
Sunnyland Slim was born on a farm in [[Quitman County, Mississippi|Quitman County]], near [[Vance, Mississippi]].<ref name="russell"/><ref name="aristocrat"/> He moved to [[Memphis, Tennessee]] in 1925, where he performed with many of the popular blues musicians of the day. His [[stage name]] came from a song he composed about the Sunnyland train that ran between Memphis and [[St. Louis, Missouri]].<ref name="russell"/> In 1942 he followed the [[great migration (African American)|great migration]] of southern workers to the industrial north in Chicago. 

At that time the [[electric blues]] was taking shape there, and through the years Sunnyland Slim played with such musicians as [[Muddy Waters]], [[Howlin' Wolf]],<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ux6N00CwudA&NR=1 |title=Howlin' Wolf - Shake It For Me |publisher=YouTube |date=2006-09-15 |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref> [[Robert Lockwood, Jr.]], and [[Little Walter]].<ref name="russell"/> His piano style is characterised by heavy basses or vamping chords in the left hand and [[tremolo]]s with his right. His voice was loud and he sang in a declamatory style.<ref name=bluesoff>{{cite book|last=Oliver|first=Paul|title=Blues Off the Record:Thirty Years of Plue Commentary|publisher=Da Capo|year=1984|location=New York|pages=201–203|isbn=0-306-80321-6}}</ref>

Sunnyland Slim's first [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] was as a singer with [[Jump Jackson]]'s band on the [[Specialty Records|Specialty label]] in September 1946.  His first recordings as a leader were on the [[Hy-Tone Records|Hy-Tone]] and [[Aristocrat Records|Aristocrat]] labels in late 1947.<ref name="hy-tone">{{cite web |url= http://hubcap.clemson.edu/~campber/hytone.html|title= The Hy-Tone Label|first= Robert |last= Pruter|coauthors=Robert L. Campbell, Tom Kelly|date= June 21, 2009|work= |publisher= Red Saunders Research Foundation|accessdate=February 7, 2010}}</ref>  Slim continued performing until his death in 1995.

He released one [[gramophone record|record]] on [[RCA Records|RCA Victor]] using the moniker '[[Doctor Clayton|Dr. Clayton]]'s Buddy': "Illinois Central" b/w "Sweet Lucy Blues" ([[Victor Records|Victor]] 20-2733).

In the late 1960s, Slim became friends with [[Canned Heat]] and played piano on the track "Turpentine Moan" on the album ''[[Boogie with Canned Heat]]''. In turn, members of Canned Heat - lead guitarist [[Henry Vestine]], slide guitarist [[Alan Wilson (musician)|Alan Wilson]] and bassist [[Larry Taylor]] - guested on Sunnyland Slim's [[Liberty Records]] album ''Slim's Got His Thing Goin' On'' (1968), which also featured [[Mick Taylor]].

In 1988 he was awarded a [[National Heritage Fellowship]].<ref name="russell"/> 

Sunnyland Slim died in March 1995 in Chicago, after complications from [[renal failure]], at the age of 88.<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1995.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 1994 - 1995 |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref>
